RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

PORTSMOUTH GASEOUS DIFFUSION PLANT



INTRODUCTION

                                                                                    

The United States Enrichment Company [USEC] has prepared an updated Risk Management 

Plan [RMP] for the Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant [PORTS] in accordance with 

the requirements set forth in Environmental Protection Agency [EPA] regulations 40 

CFR Part 68 "Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs 

Under Clean Air Act Section 112(r)(7) Subpart G - Risk Management Plan." Changes 

from the original RMP submitted in 1999 include the splitting one of the original 

processes into two processes and recalculation of the release endpoints using the 

EPA approved program RMP*Comp.  This resulted in a change in the Worst Case Toxic 

Release.

                                                                                    

The Clean Air Act Section 112(r) consists of two components for risk management of 

hazardous and toxic materials and related process systems - the Occupational Safety 

and Health Administration's [OSHA] 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management [PSM] 

Standard and 40 CFR 68.  The PORTS plant is subject to both PSM and RMP chemical 

safety management responsibilities.  

                                                                                    

The gaseous diffusion process to enrich uranium requires certain hazardous chemicals

that are managed to an acceptable risk.  The gaseous diffusion process at PORTS is 

now in standby, but the maximum inventory of the chemicals subject to the RMP rules 

is unchanged.  USEC has the management systems, risk control programs, and policy 

and practices to effectively address operational chemical risks.  These operational 

risks are managed from an accidental release prevention emphasis.  The USEC 

chemical risk management programs and systems are based upon nearly fifty years 

s

afe operating experience and the application of 10 CFR 76 requirements for a 

nuclear fuel cycle facility.  The Nuclear Regulatory Commission [NRC] approved 

Certification, required for operation, includes chemical safety as an integral 

program along with an on-going commitment to manage hazardous chemicals.  

                                                                                    

The Certification Application includes detailed management systems descriptions that

are effectively implemented for chemical safety operations, concerns, and issues.  

The management systems ensure that chemical risks are properly identified and the 

necessary management rigor is implemented to mitigate chemical operating risks and 

consequences.

                                                                                    

The technical basis of chemical safety is the Safety Analysis Report [SAR].  The SAR

describes the uranium enrichment operations and the management systems and programs 

used for operating the plant.  Chemical risks to the workers, the public and the 

environment are addressed by safety analyses, process hazard analyses [PHA], 

commercial safety and health guidance, and an emergency preparedness program.  

                                                                                    

In addition to the NRC Certification process, PORTS is also covered by and in 

compliance with the OSHA PSM and the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know 

Act [EPCRA] Section 302.  PORTS has recieved a Title V permit from the state of Ohio

in accordance with the applicable state regulations, but the permit has not yet been

issued. 

                                                                                    

PORTS has three toxic chemicals in threshold quantities stipulated in 40 CFR 68, 

Appendix A: chlorine, fluorine and anhydrous hydrogen fluoride [HF].  These three 

chemicals are used in three separate processes (origin

ally classed as only two 

processes).  PORTS does not have any flammable chemicals subject to the RMP 

regulations.

                                                                                    

Process One - Chlorine

                                                                                    

PORTS has its own water treatment plant that provides water for process cooling and 

sanitary purposes.  The X-611 Water Treatment facilities, capable of treating over 

20 million gallons of water per day, produces up to 6 million gallons per day using

 a chlorine treatment process.  The sanitary water treatment process is similar to 

other water treatment plants throughout the United States that use chlorine to 

disinfect the water for sanitary purposes. 

                                                                                    

The chlorine, provided in 2,000 pound cylinders, has a maximum administrative limit 

of three filled chlorine cylinders at any one time.  This quantity is in excess of 

the threshold quantities listed in 40 CFR 68.  A typical working inventory is two 

cylinders attached to the system manifold.  The third container, if present, would 

be in an unconnected storage position adjacent to the in-use cylinders.  All three 

container positions are inside a building with a vehicle door to accommodate 

deliveries.

                                                                                    

The alternate chlorine release scenario is based on a failure of the connector (a 

"pigtail") between the system manifold and a cylinder that causes both connected 

cylinders to be released into the building at the calculated maximum flow rate 

through the manifold.  This flow rate was calculated using a computer program called

PIPELEAK and is part of the NRC-approved SAR.  Again, holdup within the building 

reduces the release rate to the air by a factor of 0.55 and the distance to the 

endpoint is taken from RMP*Com

p.  The chlorine system has both manual and automatic 

shutoff systems that would limit an actual release, but no credit was taken for 

these systems in this analysis.



Process Two - Fluorine and Hydrogen Fluoride

                                                                                    

The X-342 fluorine generation complex produces fluorine from HF.  The HF is received

in 850 pound cylinders, with up to two cylinders connected to the fluorine 

generation system inside a heated cabinet within the X-342 building.  Additional 

cylinders are staged in a separate room (Process 3).  The HF is electrolytically 

disassociated into hydrogen, which is discharged to the atmosphere, and fluorine, 

which is stored in a set of tanks enclosed in a third room.  The fluorine is used as

needed in the maintenance of the uranium enrichment equipment.  

                                                                                    

The X-342 fluorine complex has the potential to release up to 1,290 pounds of 

fluorine or 1,700 pounds of HF.  The HF has an physical limit of two filled 

cylinders (nominally 850 pounds of HF per container) in use.  The fluorine 

has an administrative limit of 1,290 pounds.  Both these quantities are in 

excess of the threshold quantities listed in 40 CFR 68.

                                                                                    

The postulated worst case release scenario is based on an unspecified accident 

inside the fluorine building that ruptures the system manifold and storage tanks, 

causing the maximum inventory to be released within the building in ten minutes.  

Holdup within the building reduces the release rate to the air by a factor of 0.55, 

as per the EPA's Offsite Consequence Analysis [OCA] Guidelines.  The distance to 

the endpoint is taken from RMP*Comp.

                                                                                    

PORTS also considered a catastrophic failure of

the two HF cylinders.  Even allowing

for the HF to form a dense gas, however, the distance to the endpoint was shorter 

than the fluorine release distance.

                                                                                    

The alternate release scenario for fluorine involves a break in the interconnecting 

piping between the fluorine storage tanks.  The alternate release scenario for HF 

involves a failure of the pigtail between the system manifold and one of the 

connected HF cylinders.  In both scenarios, the maximum allowable inventory is 

released into the room at a flow rate calculated with PIPELEAK.  Holdup within 

the building reduces the release rate to the air by a factor of 0.55 and the 

distances to the endpoint is taken from RMP*COMP.  No credit is taken for the 

enclosure used with the HF cylinders nor for the manual and automatic shutoff 

systems that would limit the magnitude of an actual release.



Process Three - Hydrogen Fluoride

                                                                                    

The X-342 fluorine generation stores HF for the production of fluorine.  In the 

original RMP, this was included as part of Process 2 above.  During the last RMP 

inspection, the senior inspector advised PORTS that the storage of the HF cylinders

in a room adjacent to the fluorine generation needed to be considered a separate 

process.

                                                                                    

The HF is received in 850 pound cylinders.  Additional cylinders are staged in a 

separate room from the fluorine generation process within the same building.  

Individual cylinders are moved to the feed cabinet as needed.  The X-342 fluorine

generation complex has an administrative limit of eight filled cylinders staged for 

use (including the two cylinders actually in use).  Stored cylinders, holding a 

maximum of 5,100 pounds (six cylinders in storage) of HF are adjacent to, bu

t 

not connected to, each other.  

                                                                                    

The alternate release scenario for HF involves a failure of one of the stored 

cylinders' valves.  The maximum accessable inventory (850 pounds) is released 

into the room at a flow rate calculated with PIPELEAK.  The flowrate is 

substantially the same as in the alternative HF release scenario in the 

fluorine generation process.  Holdup within the building reduces the release 

rate to the air by a factor of 0.55 and the distance to the endpoint is taken 

from RMP*Comp.  



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC

PREVENTION STEPS

                                                                                    

USEC has addressed release potentials and risks in safety analysis documents and by 

the use of management systems.  Details of these mitigative actions to ensure safe 

operating conditions can be found in "Application For United States Nuclear 

Regulatory Commission Certification Portsmouth Gaseous Diffusion Plant Safety 

Analysis Report" and in 29 CFR 1910.119 PHAs for the X-342 Fluorine Generation 

Complex and the X-611E Water Treatment Facility.

                                                                                    

These site-level systems apply uniformly for the management of structures, systems, 

programs, and components that pertain to a RMP covered process and related 

activities.



Five-Year Accident History

                                                                                   

PORTS five year history exhibits a chemical release performance of no significant or

threshold quantity release of chlorine, fluorine, or HF.  Minor releases can occur 

during routine operations and maintenance activities, but have not resulted in 

significant personnel exposure or environmental impacts.  



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

During the process of transition from a Department of Energy [DOE]-regulated 

environment to that of a commercial private industry (1993-1998), a detailed 

Compliance Plan was prepared by the DOE to ensure upgrades were implemented where 

needed to comply with commercial and NRC requirements.  This Compliance Plan 

represented any planned changes needed to improve site safety that included 

chemical safety related activities.  The Compliance Plan is comprehensive and 

includes the use of hazardous or toxic chemicals by near-by third parties which 

may impact USEC operations and personnel.  

                                                                                    

Additionally, Memorandums of Understanding were implemented between the OSHA, the 

NRC, and the EPA to share and reinforce regulatory compliance and safety 

performance.  

                                                                                    

During this transitional period, plant operations and activities were reviewed and 

upgraded to ensure a safe operation.  Reviews of chemical safety-related areas 

included improved and upgraded safety analysis documentation, facility and equipment

descriptions, quantitative hazard and accident analyses, classifications of safety 

structures, systems, and components and programmatic controls.  Additional 

improvements addressed included hazardous material protection [chemical safety], 

initial testing, in-service surveillance and maintenance testing; operational 

safety; procedures and training, quality assurance, emergency preparedness program 

management organization, and institutional safety provisions.  Each of these 

functional areas have appropriate applications to the 40 CFR 68 RMP.

 

USEC MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS

                                                                                    

USEC is required to describe its management controls and oversight program

governing

activities directly relevant to nuclear safety safeguards, and security in 

accordance with 10 CFR 76.35(a)(7).  USEC has functional, administrative, and 

technical management systems to implement RMP requirements.  These plant systems and

programs, based upon 10 CFR 76 requirements, are applicable to the RMP covered 

processes as well as the general operation of the plant.  These management systems 

are implemented by formal procedures and program policies.  The following is a brief

description and basis for the applicable management systems used for chemical risk 

management.

 

Management and Organization

                                                                                    

USEC is committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and 

safety of workers and the public, protects the environment, and provides for the 

common defense and security.  To meet these commitments, as well as others required 

for the operation of the uranium enrichment enterprise, USEC has issued an 

operations policy manual which contains statements of policy and procedures for 

day-to-day business operations and provides direction to USEC employees.  USEC 

policy states, in part:

                                                                                    

     " USEC is ultimately responsible for, and is committed to safe operations,

     maintenance, modification, design, fabrication, and testing of the Portsmouth

     Gaseous Diffusion Plant [GDP], and is committed to conducting operations in a

     manner that protects the health and safety of workers and the public, protects 

     the environment and provides for the common defense and security.  USEC has

     provided the management structure to ensure that the safety/safeguards policy 

     is effectively implemented."

                                                                                    

The management system includes the organizations

and structure, the manager's title,

the managers' roles and responsibilities, and establishes accountabilities for their

functional assignments.  

                                                                                    

Fundamentally, the line organizations are responsible for the safe operation of the 

GDP.  Programs and staff organizations are established for Safety, Safeguards, and 

Quality and Environmental, Safety, and Health [ES&H], with sufficient resources to 

support the line organizations in safe operation of the GDP.

 

Safety Information Review

                                                                                    

Safety information policy and procedures are established formal documents that 

define safe operating parameters for plant operations.  The engineering function and

management systems control chemical hazards and chemical usages at PORTS.  

Engineering is responsible for the generation, application, and overall management 

of process safety information as it applies to chemical safety, structures, systems,

and components.  

                                                                                    

Process safety information is reviewed and approved as identified in the 

implementation procedures.  These reviews and approvals vary in accordance 

with the application of graded risk.  

                                                                                    

An Engineering Service Order [ESO] is required for modifications to existing 

systems.  The ESO process provides a mechanism that identifies new or revised 

usages of chemicals, chemical processes, and/or associated logistics that require 

engineering involvement.  The engineering management system utilizes independent 

and multi-discipline reviews and approvals for ESO-related activities.  

                                                                                    

Engineering and quality records are processed

and maintained in accordance with 

Quality Assurance, Records Management, and Document Control program requirements 

as discussed in the Recordkeeping Section of this RMP.

                                                                                    

Periodic programmatic reports, field validation requirements, configuration 

management reviews and assessment, and independent evaluation processes are used as 

part of the engineering management system for process safety information.



Process Hazard Analyses and Methodology Used

                                                                                    

Safety Analysis Report - The SAR describes the technical basis program requirements 

for chemical safety; the integration of chemical safety with the uranium enrichment 

operations; and describes the management systems used for chemical safety.  The SAR 

is subject to upgrades and revisions as required to ensure continued safe operations

including revisions related to chemical process safety.

                                                                                    

Process Hazard Analysis - Chemicals are used at PORTS that are managed in accordance

with 29 CFR 1910.119 PSM requirements.  The PSM program manages these hazardous 

chemicals in a manner that prevents impact to workers and the public.  The hazard 

analyses are used to identify and manage chemical risks and impacts to plant systems

or operations, workers and to the public.  Specific job-related risks, the technical

controls and administrative controls used for risk management are addressed in the 

specific PHAs.  

                                                                                    

The OSHA PHAs used the "Failure Mode and Effects" methodology to identify the 

potential hazards and risks.  The PHAs were prepared by PORTS safety analysis 

personnel or the use of consultants having related professional credentials.  The 

PHAs were reviewed, re

vised and upgraded as controlled documents in October, 1998.

                                                                                    

Industrial Hygiene and Safety Program Hazard Analysis - Commercial chemicals, such 

as HF and chlorine, have varying toxicity and hazardous ranges and categories of 

consequences.  Industrial hygiene and safety program applications provides accepted 

industrial standards and regulatory requirements for protection from hazardous 

chemicals during daily operations and emergency responses.  



Corrective Actions Management System 

                                                                                    

Plant problems, issues, and concerns are addressed in accord with the USEC Quality 

Assurance Plan [QAP].  A corrective action management system, based upon the ASME 

NQA-1 requirements for Corrective Action, ensures that significant conditions 

adverse to quality are mitigated, the cause of the condition is determined, 

corrective action is taken to preclude recurrence, and ensures that followup 

actions are taken to verify implementation of the corrective actions.  These 

actions are documented and reported to appropriate levels of management in 

accordance with the implementing procedures.



Procedures Management System

                                                                                    

USEC is required to describe its management controls and oversight program governing

activities directly relevant to nuclear safety safeguards and security in accordance

with 10 CFR 76.35(a)(7).  Controlled written procedures are utilized to conduct 

operations for the protection of the general public, plant employees, and the 

environment.  A balanced combination of written guidance, craftsman skills, and work

site supervision are utilized to achieve the protection of the public, plant 

employees, and the environment.

Procedures are developed or modified through a formal process incorporating change 

controls.  The change controls establish a protocol to ensure technical, operations,

maintenance, and administrative procedures are properly developed, received, 

approved, revised and controlled.  The procedures are periodically reviewed in 

accordance with the procedure program requirements associated with the specific 

function.



Training Program 

                                                                                    

The USEC training program, established in accordance with 10 CFR 76.35(a), requires 

USEC to establish, implement and maintain a training program for individuals relied

upon to operate, maintain or modify the GDPs in a safe manner.  The training program

for such individuals shall be based upon a systems approach to training.  The USEC 

Training Program organization and administration is a full-time group that consists 

of a centralized staff reporting directly to the Training Manager.  



Equipment Inspection and Test Status 

                                                                                    

USEC Maintenance and Work Control organizations provide for the safe, reliable, and 

cost-effective maintenance of the plant.  Routine maintenance work is identified, 

prioritized, planned, scheduled, executed, and closed-out in accordance with the 

work control program requirements.  The maintenance and surveillance program 

consists of a mix of preventative maintenance, corrective maintenance, and 

calibration requirements.  Maintenance for the plant is performed in accordance 

with the Quality Assurance, Engineering and Configuration Management program

requirements.



Post Maintenance Testing

                                                                                    

Post Maintenance Testing [PMT] requirements are developed by engineering for 

commonly required repairs to verify the adequacy of

those repairs.  Special PMT 

requirements may be requested on a case-by-case basis.  PMT performance and 

acceptance is documented in the work package.



Work Control

                                                                                    

The Work Control Organization is responsible for coordinating, planning and 

scheduling of maintenance work activities; providing overall scheduling of capital 

projects; and implementing controls to provide a record of work accomplished.

                                                                                    

Authorization for release of equipment or systems for maintenance is granted by 

designated organizational managers and is documented in the work package.  

Operational authorization is based upon verification that the equipment or 

system may be taken out of service.  The work package identifies other needed 

work permits and the affected equipment or system being isolated to provide 

protection for plant personnel and equipment.  When the equipment is returned 

to service, Operations verifies and documents satisfactory completion of the post-

maintenance testing, and places the equipment in operation.

                                                                                    

For detailed history of specific system equipment and test/inspection records, the

history file is maintained by the Work Control and Records Management programs. 



Management of Change and History of Change

                                                                                    

USEC may make changes to the plant or plant operations from that described in the 

SAR provided the following provisions of 10 CFR 76.68(a) are satisfied:

                                                                                    

1.   Conduct a written safety analysis that demonstrates that the change would not 

     result in undue risk to public health and safety, the common defense and

security, or to the environment.

                                                                                    

2.   The changes must be authorized by responsible management and approved by the

     Plant Operations Review Committee [PORC].

                                                                                    

3.   The changes may not decrease effectiveness of the plant's safety, safeguards, 

     and security programs.

                                                                                    

4.   The changes may not involve a change to any condition to the certification of 

     compliance.

                                                                                    

5.   The changes may not involve a change to any condition to the approved 

     compliance plan.

                                                                                    

6.   The changes may not involve an unreviewed safety question.

                                                                                    

If the proposed change would not satisfy all of the above provisions, the change 

will not be made unless prior NRC approval is granted by the NRC in accordance with 

10 CFR 76.45.

 

Controls on change are also included in other processes as follows:

                                                                                    

As-Found Conditions - Any as-found condition that does not agree with the 

description in the SAR [including programs, plans, policies, and operations] must 

be approved in accordance with the above provisions or corrected to match the SAR.  

                                                                                    

Program Document Control - Proposed changes to the Emergency Plan [EP], QAP, or 

other non-chemical program documents are evaluated to determine whether the proposed

changes would decrease the effectiveness of the program.  Changes to these plans and

programs

cannot occur without NRC approval if changes would decrease the 

effectiveness.   These changes shall be authorized by responsible management and 

approved by the PORC.

                                                                                    

Physical Plant Changes and Configuration - The control of changes to the physical 

plant and control of the physical plant configuration are managed by the Design 

Authority [Engineering].

                                                                                    

The documents and analysis reports for changes are managed as described in the 

Recordkeeping and Controlled Document programs described elsewhere.



PRE-STARTUP REVIEW HISTORY

                                                                                    

USEC has a management system to address plant changes and the requirements to review

and approve activities prior to restart or return to operational service.  These 

reviews can be very simple to extensive efforts dependent upon the associated risk 

and sensitivity of the particular operation.  

                                                                                    

Programmatic reviews that would involve chemical safety issues include:

                                                                                    

     1.   Facility modifications, additions, or changes having a 10 CFR 76.68 review

          performed.  

                                                                                      

     2.   Modification to the facility procedures, personnel training, testing

          programs, or regulatory documents.

                                                                                    

     3.   Modifications being evaluated and documented to minimize worker exposure 

          in keeping with the facility As Low As Reasonably Achievable program, 

          nuclear criticality safety, worker safety requirements or other

restrictions.

                                                                                    

          Other areas of consideration in evaluating modifications may include 

          quality assurance, modification costs, similar completed modifications,

          potential operability or maintenance concerns, fabrication concerns, 

          environmental concerns, and human factors.

                                                                                    

     4.   Proposed facility modifications receive an independent, technical review 

          which considers the technical feasibility and merit of the proposed change

          and the identification of appropriate interfaces for inclusion in the

          change package [e.g., procedures, training, safety].

                                                                                    

A final review prior to release for operation must be performed to verify the 

following:

                                                                                    

     a.   Safety analysis documentation is complete and approved;

                                                                                    

     b.   Operational procedure changes are complete and other supporting procedure

          changes have been instituted;

                                                                                    

     c.   Operational training and qualification changes have been completed;

                                                                                    

     d.   Design changes are complete and any as-built changes are identified and

          approved;

                                                                                    

     e.   Document changes are completed; and

                                                                                    

     f.   Post-modification testing has been successfully completed.

Most Recent Pre-startup Review Applicable to RMP Requirements

                                                                                    

The only pre-startup review for a RMP facility/system was the initial startup of the

water treatment facility that increased the chlorine dwell time during processing 

water for use.  This pre-startup review was conducted in 1995.  All other facilities

have not required a pre-startup review process since the Clean Air Act amendments of

1990 became effective. 

                                                                                    

Post-maintenance testing is used as appropriate to ensure that safe operational 

status has been re-established after routine maintenance activities.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS

                                                                                    

The QAP includes an audit system which was established for Quality and Augmented 

Quality items and other activities and services within the scope of the QAP.  The 

audit systems is in accordance with Basic Requirement 18 and Supplement 18S-1 of 

NQA-1 (1989).  This system establishes planned and periodic audits to verify the 

compliance and effectiveness of the QAP in meeting quality requirements.

                                                                                    

Independent internal audits of selected aspects of operational activities are 

performed with a frequency commensurate with their safety significance and in a 

manner as to assure that audits of activities within the scope of the QAP are 

completed within the specified time periods.  Audit reports are managed as described

in the Recordkeeping and Document Control program descriptions found in other RMP 

sections.

                                                                                    

Corrective actions and issues resulting from audits, investigations, and regulatory 

sources are addressed by the Corrective Action m

anagement system discussed in this 

document.  These audits and any corrective actions are processed by existing plant 

programs that include RMP elements and requirements.

                                                                                    

The most recent compliance audit was conduted by Ohio EPA personnel, under contract 

to the federal EPA.  The audit cited no violations of the RMP requirements, but 

advised PORTS to split the HF storage into a separate process from the fluorine 

generation at the next RMP update.  The senior auditor also advised PORTS to label

empty HF cylinders in the same or nearby areas as "EMPTY" for the benefit of 

emergency responsers.

 

INCIDENT INVESTIGATIONS

                                                                                    

USEC conducts incident and event investigations to protect employees, public health 

and safety, the environment, and national security interests.  Incident 

investigations are conducted in accordance with formal procedures.  If a large scale

event were to occur, a special investigation team may be appointed to investigate 

the incident.

                                                                                    

Appropriate notification of an incident is by the specific program management and 

regulatory requirements.  Notification is performed in accordance with formal 

procedures.

                                                                                    

As part of this program, abnormal events are identified, reported, and investigated.

This includes identification, categorization of the event and analysis to determine 

the root cause and its effect. The corrective actions developed as a result of the 

investigation are entered into a commitment management database, which is a 

dedicated database used to track and trend corrective actions and plant commitments.

This database also facilitates management's review of the corrective acti

ons and 

plant commitment.



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION PLAN REVIEW AND REVISION

                                                                                    

USEC manages operational safety with an Employee Participation Plan that involves 

personnel on plant-site.  The Employee Participation Plan expresses expectations of

the plant population support and participation, and the individual's roles and 

responsibilities.  The Plan involves personnel represented by organized labor, 

salary employees, and subcontractors.

                                                                                    

The Employee Participation Plan, initially created with the Union Local Safety and 

Health Representatives in 1994, is based upon the 29 CFR 1910.119 elements and 

supported by plant policies and procedures.  The Employee Participation Plan is 

applied by formal plant implementation procedures, e.g., reporting unsafe 

activities, emergency response expectations, and configuration management controls.



HOT WORK PERMIT REVIEW/REVISION

                                                                                    

USEC maintains fire protection facilities and equipment used to protect the health 

and safety and limit danger to life or property from fires.  The fire protection 

programs draw heavily on NFPA codes and standards to provide an acceptable level of 

fire safety.  Part of the program elements used is the "hot work permit" system.  

The "hot work permit" in place is to ensure cutting, welding, and other hot work 

conducted in areas not designated or approved for such processes will be done in a 

manner that is consistent with industry fire preventative practices.  



CONTRACTOR SAFETY PROGRAM REVIEW AND SAFETY PERFORMANCE EVALUATION

                                                                                    

USEC is committed to conducting operations in a manner that protects the health and 

safety of workers and the pu

blic, protects the environment, and provides for the 

common defense and security.  To functionally address the contractor safety program 

the Engineering manager is responsible for engineering activities in support of 

operations, including project management, design, fabrication, and construction of 

plant modifications or additions; systems and reliability engineering including 

interfaces regarding predictive and preventative maintenance; nuclear safety; and 

the configuration management program.

                                                                                    

The Engineering Manager is supported by the ES&H manager.   Job specific overview is

the responsibility of the Site Technical Representative assigned to the contractor 

and includes tasks associated with or near hazardous chemicals or potential energy 

sources.  ES&H assists in areas concerning site safety requirements and chemical 

usage.  Field activities are subject to periodic visits by ES&H personnel.

                                                                                    

Contractor personnel are trained to site requirements appropriate to their assigned

tasks. Unless otherwise indicated by contract, contractors are responsible to use 

and follow site procedures and safety requirements.

                                                                                    

There has been no contractor work on the covered processes since the original RMP 

was submitted in 1999.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

                                                                                    

USEC has established and prepared an EP to ensure that plant personnel are 

adequately prepared for accidents and effective response actions are taken to 

mitigate the consequences of such accidents and emergencies, and to protect the

health and safety of the public and the workers at the plant.  The emergency 

planning requirements set forth in 10 CFR 70 for ot

her nuclear fuel cycle facilities

are appropriate for the GDPs and that the requirements in 10 CFR 76.91 are based 

upon the emergency planning provisions in 10 CFR 70.  Accordingly, the format of 

the EP is generally based upon NRC Regulatory Guide 3.67, Standard Format and 

Content for Emergency Plans for Fuel Cycle and Materials Facilities.  

                                                                                    

The EP provides an overall description of the site-wide emergency preparedness 

program, which is based, on a large measure on the emergency preparedness policies,

procedures, and practices that have been successfully used at PORTS for over 40 

years.  This program has been established to manage and respond in a consistent 

and integrated fashion to accidents or other emergency situations that may occur

at the site.

                                                                                    

The structure of this program is intended to ensure that the consequences of 

emergencies are promptly mitigated and that the health and safety of the public, 

personnel on the surrounding DOE reservation, and plant personnel are protected, 

regardless of the cause or nature of the accident.  Therefore, the EP addresses 

both radiological and non-radiological emergencies as well as potential emergencies 

arising out of activities at the site that are not regulated by the NRC.  Emergency 

Plan elements include:

                                                                                    

     a general description of the plant and the surrounding area;



     accidents and the emergencies for which protective actions may be needed;

     accident detection and classification;



     policies and procedures;



     notification of and communication with plant, local governments, and

     regulatory agencies in the event of an emergency;



     coordination of the emergency response activities of both on-site and

off-site response organizations;



     responsibilities of the key individuals and organizations involved in

     emergency esponse activities;



     mitigation and consequences analyses of an emergency;



     maintenance of emergency response equipment, facilities, and capabilities;

     training and exercises;



     restoration of plant equipment and systems to safe condition after an

     accident; and



     topics required under 10 CFR 76.91.  

                                                                                    

The EP is maintained and updated by USEC in accordance with 10 CFR 76.91(o) and 

EPCRA.  As such, USEC may change the EP without receiving prior NRC approval, 

provided the change does not decrease the effectiveness of the EP and the NRC 

and affected offsite response organizations are provided with copies of any 

changes to the EP.

                                                                                    

Memorandums of Understanding have been implemented between the OSHA, the NRC, and 

the EPA to ensure regulatory compliance and safe performance.  



RMP DOCUMENT UPGRADES

                                                                                    

Planned and periodic upgrades to RMP documents and submittals will be addressed by 

the Plant Change Review process, the Business Practice Services tracking database, 

and the Configuration Management program.  This provides the management system an 

approach to address the periodic upgrade requirement.  Regulatory upgrades may 

result from the following:

                                                                                    

Regulatory changes - Regulatory actions resulting in a system or process scope 

change will be addressed by the Change Control process.

                                                                                    

New or modified processes - New or modified processes utilizing threshold quantities

of regulated chemicals will be addressed by the Change Control system and plant 

management systems previously discussed in this RMP.  

                                                                                    

Program Criteria Change/Revision -  Program criteria that result in a process or 

system change resulting from a revised PHA or a hazard review would be addressed 

primarily by the Corrective Action program.



RECORDKEEPING

                                                                                    

The Records Management and Document Control programs are established to ensure 

records and documents required by the QAP are appropriately designed to meet the 

specific recordkeeping and document control requirements set forth in 10 CFR 76.

                                                                                    

These systems provide administrative controls that establish standard methods and 

requirements for collection, maintenance, distributing, and disposing records.  

                                                                                    

Records Management Program

                                                                                    

The Records Management program provides direction for the handling, transmittal, 

storage, and retrieval of records.  Record media may include microfilm, electronic 

[magnetic or optical], or hard copy.  Records are categorized and handled in 

accordance with their relative importance to safety and storage needs.  Specific 

records are maintained for a period of time specified by applicable NRC, Federal, 

or State requirements.  



Document Control Program

                                                                                    

The Document Control program provides direction for the handling, distribution, and 

transmittal of documents important to nuclear safety, safeguards, and security that 

specify quality requirements or pres

cribe activities affecting quality, such as 

procedures, drawings, and calculations.  

                                                                                    

For documents and changes to documents dictated by the QAP, requirements are 

established for approval and release of those documents for distribution.  Certain 

critical documents requiring review and approval by the PORC are identified in the

Technical Safety Requirements [TSR] for the PORC.  

                                                                                    

Requirements for the review and approval of procedures are identified in the TSR for

procedures and in the formal procedures program.

 

AVAILABILITY OF INFORMATION TO THE PUBLIC

                                                                                    

Controlled copies of the RMP will be provided in accordance with the EPA 

instructions and guidance prescribed in 40 CFR 68.  Fulfillment of the RMP 

requirements will not involve classified data information or other intelligence 

that might be of national or company security.  USEC does reserve the rights and 

provisions to address exceptions to this issue with the EPA and other agencies as 

may be required.



AUDITS BY REGULATORY AGENCIES    

                                                                                    

Regulatory agency audits will be addressed by the management systems described 

herein and in the implementing procedures as well as the requirements and guiding 

criteria of the regulating agency.  Audit corrective actions or issues generated 

by regulatory agency reviews will be managed and processed as applicable within 

the framework of these same systems to ensure management responsiveness.
